lw2GRgIMoHFnEJnO-N3JPw.text: I've been here twice. The first time around, I went for a normal falafel with pita. I wasn't impressed. The second time around, about eight months later, I decided to give them a second chance and went for a falafel with guacamole on pita. Colour me most unimpressed. I couldn't taste any guacamole, my pita was lukewarm, and, the only thing I registered was that the falafel was crunchy. This may be sacrilegious but I prefer the falafel from Pret. Not only is it cheaper, but it tastes better too.

QOMNjkGGVZJUtqaWa6YKTQ.text: If heaven were diving face first into a pitta filled with fucking awesome, then Pilpel is your pearly gate, my friend.

J3h2ttwgaid2ORWe-z4pKw.text: Sometimes a type of food just hits the zeitgeist.  It used to be Mexican and now London is flooded by burrito bar this, burrito bar that.  Obviously the whole falafel and houmous thing isn't new, soho is stuffed with little houmous bars, however, the City of London gets things a bit late, a bit slower.   Don't worry though, since Pilpel is here now and it is good.  It is perfect timing as sitting outside with a bowl of middle eastern salad and falafel suits this oppresive 'english summer' we are having.  The only problem with Pilpel is that everyone else realises this and the queues are crazy.  It's the new burrito

QROn0IcZ4xWKYbAI8LAnWw.text: A little bit of Israeli sunshine on a mixed day in London. Well this takeaway with a few tiny breakfast bar style tables offered hot fresh falafel with extras such as feta, hummus and aubergines. Unlike Maoz, you don't get to fill your own pitta or salad bowl. But filling was very generous. There are other items such as sabich.  The Israeli effect is emphasised by the choice of native branded soft drinks. I've never been to Tel Aviv but I did feel for a little while I was not in London anymore. The only gripe was the Q's but it soon moved very quickly.

9NwIZOldVWNcWjaxqhAqig.text: Pilpel is absolutely my favorite lunch spot . There are probably enough restaurants around Spitalfields Market that you could go to a different one every day and not eat at the same place twice in 3 months. Pilpel opened a little over a month ago , and I've got my lunch there there around a half-dozen times.Pilpel is a very simple eatery- the name gives you the width and breadth of the menu: falafel and houmous. There's dozens of different options for how you can have your falafel (with aubergines, carrots, cucumber salad, olives etc.) but if falafel isn't what you're after then this isn't your place. If you are after falafel though, then this is where you should go. It's absolutely the best stuff I've had in London.You can have a good lunch here for less than a fiver, served to you by a cheerful staff (and more often than not, the owner). They just set up some tables outside, too - so if you've got a long lunch break you can sit oin the sun with your meal.

RGVaY4wjT7lBFPCHwKiHpw.text: Amazing falafel place. If you think you don't like falafels, go here and you will! They have a crispy skin and are fresh and not dry inside. You often get a free one in the queue. The pitta and the salad are huge and stuffed properly full and delicious!Top tip - the smaller stall at the edge of Spitalfields does 4 falafel in a box for £1, with chili and tahini sauce. I often bring in my own salad and get these for a warm and filling top up. You can't even buy them that cheap in the supermarket!

l1zn_rODdUJHGEWoEGrlgg.text: Excellent, good tasting, reasonable value, filling, friendly staff.I often eat here. The best Falafels I have had. Great, clean, healthy food.Long queues that go down quickly. A 'must try' place.

mk7kHvrUxzAZMzCrmuYSDg.text: I LOVE this place.  This is my vegetarian colleague and mine's default place to have lunch.  The only serve falafel's so they know that they are doing!  it's only 4 for a falafel filled pita and 5 for the falafel plate.  I would suggest just getting the falafel pita.There is normally a line during lunch time, but they are pretty quick.  It's plenty of time to run over there, grab your lunch, and run back to sit with your colleagues for the last 30 mins.There really aren't any seats so expect to eat somewhere else.  On a nice day we sit in the outdoor 'tarp' covered seating area across the street in Spitalfields.

0mp49xybV_s03bU6byeLDw.text: I used to live next to a corner shop that sold falafels in the back.  I used to be hooked on those falafels and never really found anything as good until Pilpel.  I'm still trying to figure out which i like more..The thing that so good about pilpel is that you can cram so much shizznazz into your pita.  and its only 4 quid!  i think it would have been better if i had more chili and tahini sauce on top as well as with in the pita...but now i just know to ask for that next time.there was a line but it moved pretty quickly

G9MlsnrLsrP3p-KporcYGw.text: If I'm feeling veggie, Pilpel is definitely my first stop for lunch. The falafel are tasty, fresh and crispy and they put loads of salads in so a meat-eater like me doesn't end up going hungry. The place is usually very busy at lunchtimes, but the queues move quickly. Try it with halloumi-- one of my favourite addons. Delicious. Oh and the fruit nectars are good and compliment the sandwiches nicely!

UzYWKkee-LSRGN-4QF9gZw.text: Pilpel has changed my life. Those little falafels of joy with tahini - not found anywhere better. Service always outstanding with free falafels while you wait. Bok or Pita - both amazing and very fresh range of salads. Highly reccomend!

6mHvwDkyJTZL6Dj9BKonvw.text: Best falafel in London. Much much fresher than Maoz and very friendly. Tips: Get there before 12 30pm. You can just have falafel on their own (with tahini and chilli sauce). its 70p for three, £1.40 for six etc. The lemonade isnt great

B5c0HZ6vg3kH3XgthAmrDw.text: Man this place is GOOD. About £4.50 for a big falafel salad bowl, and £3.90 for a falafel with pita. They pile on the salads -- shredded cabbage, parsley salad, carrots, onions, chickpeas, a big healthy dollop of hummus... MMM. And for one salad bowl, they give you SIX plump falafels. I couldn't finish mine. So good. One of the better quick bites (and decently healthy) options around the City. Quality of food is fresh. WOOP!

6druQhW2gFcgJCQ-oDpR1w.text: This place has the tastiest, juiciest falafel I've had. I get there around 13:00 and it is usually crowded.  The food is definitely worth 5 stars but after a few minutes of waiting inside the smell from the kitchen can get in the clothes.

b2FhPUuw7rjyWDFUyyke9g.text: I was starving before checking out Spitalfields Market one day, and I came across Pilpel - so glad I did! This was a fantastic, super filling lunch, and maybe the cheapest meal I had during my trip to London. I got a falafel sandwich on a wholemeal pita, and it was stuffed with tons of different salads and sauces. I wish I had one of these at home - I would definitely be a regular!

photos.caption: Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom

ECfVqnlmZmttShpZJFI-bA.text: Fresh Falafel! Quantity is mind blowing! I had Falafel in a container (not as big as those ship containers). But it was quite a lot. You should be really hungry to finish it all. This place is HOT! I mean hot in demand. The queues during lunch time are simply out of this world. Everyone loves falafel from here. And you get to taste a sample when you are in queue. There is one random pilpel guy who walks around with a plate of falafel and tahini and spicy sauce to get a taste. Very popular among my friends too. This particular store has a lot of vegetarian options! This was a surprise! But the demand says it all. You should try it to understand what I mean.

j9LoyQ18y-Z0v7D1YwI1Aw.text: NOTE:  I think there are now 2 locations for Pilpel.  I believe there is a shop and then a little street market counter shop located in the Old Spitalfields area.  We were at the counter shop.Stopped by here yesterday with some girls from work on our lunch break.  It was a beautiful sunny day and a little walk in the sunshine and some window shopping at Spitalfields market was just what we needed.It was so hot so we didn't want anything too heavy to eat.  Two of us opted for Pilpel.  We were totally confused by the menu and the girls behind the counter kind of bark at you in a polite way but from the fresh food behind the counter, I knew it was going to be good.There is just a counter and not a shop that you go into to order. Very street food-esk.  I have NO idea what I ordered but it had pita, falafal, chickpeas, tabouleh salad, tahini (I think), onions and houmus.  It was awesome!  It was filling but not heavy.I can't wait to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom. I love chickpeas!
Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom. Pilpel = yum

x9O2BcOl_ixaLlfgkYIRaw.text: Great falafal lunch spot in the City. I still prefer the fresh falafal from market stand, but this place has more salad and sauce choices for u,  in a take away box or wrap format. Just remember To eat it fresh!! Taste harsh Zhen falafal turns cold.

fKs-qvDmSyP8xx04aeLfag.text: I love it. Amazingly delicious WHOLEMEAL pitta properly stuffed with salad and falafels poured over with range of yummy sauces - gives you a great value for money, yet succulent lunch!Falafel & houmus are their trademarks, so make sure you go for these at least once you go there. I've been there on numerous occassions (most of them were successful attempts to convert my colleagues into healthy eaters) and every single time - during lunchbreak - there are queues. But! not to worry - their services is pretty quick!Advice: if you have a bit of spare time and do not need to stuff in your lunch infront of your laptop - go to Pilpel in Spitalfields market - it has a lot more seats and it's under a roof which is beneficial if it's rainy outside :)Warning: their pittas ARE very filling, so I either go for a salad option (pitta free), or have less falafels, as otherwise I feel like hibernating after my lunch!If you are determined to go to the Brushfield st branch - go there slightly early - eg 12.30, rather than 1pm to grab a table, as they are very limited.

-QfynFBpo_9NmzX3WnKtuA.text: I got a bowl here, and thought it was good. There is a place at home that is really good, so any similar place gets compared to it, and I just don't like this one as much.

yK7IrDTXmNUuHh8SLdkumg.text: Pilpel is without a doubt the best meal (or 50 meals) that I had during my semester studying abroad in London. Let's start with the food. Pilpel keeps it simple. They do falafel, and they do it better than just about anyone else. Upon entering the restaurant, you place your order at the counter. You can either order your falafel in a pita, or opt for it on a bed of your choice of fresh toppings. You can choose from a variety of crisp vegetables and flavorful spreads, such as carrots, chickpeas, red and white cabbage, tabbouleh, carrots, jalapenos, pickled cucumbers and lettuce. Personally, I load up my pita with a little bit of everything, as I find that all of the flavors blend together magically to create a little slice of heaven inside that pita. Last, but certainly not least, you'll be asked what sauces and spreads you would like added. You must get extra tahini sauce. I REPEAT, YOU MUST GET EXTRA TAHINI SAUCE. This is the key to creating the best falafel pita you will ever have. Also make sure to ask for a little chilli sauce to spice things up, and some hummus. For .60p extra, you can choose to add feta, aubergine, guacamole, or a hard boiled egg. I enjoy adding feta or guacamole when I'm feeling a little feisty, but find the aubergine a little too salty. Every single person that I've brought here, and I seemed to bring just about anyone I knew in London during my time there, fell in love with this place. This became my go-to place to have a quick lunch or dinner, and it's perfect for those on a budget, as portions are large and prices are pretty low, at least for London.The employees here are always smiling and will never hesitate to help you out if you have a question or want a recommendation. On my last day in town, they even gave me a free Pilpel shirt to wear back here in the States. Great service is just the cherry on top of this scrumptious, fantastic cake. Next time you're in the Spitalfields area, make sure to check out Pilpel. Even if you're not in the area, it's worth a tube ride to check this gem out.

photos.caption: Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom. Favorite restaurant in London, wearing the free Pilpel shirt I was given!

kK79_CKwG5P3sDKNZ_gc5g.text: I'm a big fan of Pilpel.  Their falafel is consistently good, and the containers come with a great array of salads, humous, plus a choice of two different chilli sauces (best to ask for both) and a choice of white or wholemeal pita.  It's not the cheapest falafel place (£5.65 for a box or a pound less if you just want a wrap), but it's worth it.  It can get busy at lunch time, but the staff will often compensate you for the wait by giving you a free individual falafel to taste as you queue.  I always pay an extra 70p for four extra falafel.

3xbevqUzhSfhU6MWl0-Yow.text: Every person I've brought here has come back and brought others..and you can tell as the queue gets longer but they are still able to get through the masses. Best falafel ever. I only get annoyed that I don't always get a cheeky freebie while waiting in the queue.

mYc1wGLuBO8eXlHiESLmxg.text: Living a block away for 5 months gave me the pleasure of being able to eat at Pilpel at least twice a week. By far the best falafels in London and the best I've ever had outside of Mamouns in NYC. This massive pita sandwich filled with orgasmic flavors could satisfy the hungriest of people all for an affordable price. Always long lines around noon due to the work flow.The must:Falafel on brown pita with all toppings and guacamole, feta cheese and aubergines and tahini (chili sauce is awesome as well).After leaving London to back to New York, I'm definitely in a Pilpel falafel withdrawal.

YeDLrCqynrnuOiIYa9d3-Q.text: Bad excuse for middle eastern food. You'll have better luck finding good middle eastern food on brick lane. ;)

EjpN6UiiZYUndmMOjr8NIA.text: If you get a hankering for falafel while shopping at Spitalfields, this is the place to go!  I was debating where to have lunch when one of the guys here offered me a free sample of their falafel, and that made the decision for me.  You can get guac and salad and all kinds of delightful toppings (I had no idea guac went with falafel, but let me tell you, it DOES).  Reasonably priced and very filling.  Good quality ingredients and friendly staff.

x_J-_zLUsZ_NAyxTmpV8LA.text: Great food - but not to keen on the service. I think the place is good - it's jam packed at lunch - but to be fair the manager is super agressive and there's not too much of a good vibe going on. I'll be back for the food though. It really is the best in London. Proper Israeli style!

ztIdwaiBpvqgPRhFw3W4hw.text: Very fresh and crunchy falafel. Well worth the price. If you have to wait in line, someone walks around handing out free falafel balls.

hMr1SPUnHc0_TTcjmwTdIA.text: I heard of this place from a colleague who recommended it very highly for its freshness and simplicity. And off I trotted to this place the following week and considering the non-trivial walk from my workplace to this establishment, I figured I was setting myself up for a disappointment. But voila, what's this I see? A fast moving queue, friendly staff, crisp and fresh salad items layered up on a bed of the most delish houmous, a generous portion of six falafels (yes, six!) all packed neatly in a box and most unexpectedly, a generous portion of the home-baked flatbread too! I had asked for a topping off aubergines too and I thought it was a nice  touch...At a mere 5.40quid or thereabouts, I was pleased to note that I was well satiated and felt full even up to the point that I sat down to dinner later that day.This is obviously designed to be a take-away place but there are a few wooden stools about the place and I ate in there, noting the busy but quick turnaround at the counter. My only qualm about the place was the excessive packaging including box lids and big brown paper bags given to all customers regardless of their intent to eat in...the mass of brown paper bag in the trashbin seemed like needless waste.That apart, I think I have found myself a new lunch place for days when I fancy a bit of a walk :)

290Mz8Qsyq5tCeh5GXRzbw.text: Pilpel is a busy, but great lunch place just outside Spitalfileds Market. It's not a place to sit down, but rather a place to pick up and eat outside on a bench or take back to your desk. The menu is pretty straightforward and offers made-from-scratch falafel and houmous on the premises. If you're adventurous and unafraid of making a mess, go for the goods with all the salad inside a pitta, but if you're like me, you'll spend an extra 50p and put it in a container. My lunch took me two days to eat! That's how big the portion was...and cheap too! This is definitely a nice, healthy and fast addition to the many food spots in the area. Let the vegetarians rejoice!

photos.caption: Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom

HqRHQnYaECYSOQ9UnnaBQg.text: I have eaten at this place twice now and will definitely be back next time I am in London. I got the guacamole and falafel in a pita and it was fabulous. I would highly recommend it. The falafel and veggies are very fresh. Definitely a good place to stop and grab a quick lunch while walking through the old spitafields market.

88_2YCoAbR1Wn-OPhd_0XQ.text: If you find yourself trekking through the East End, this place is a must.   You should really make the effort to eat here before they get more popular, over crowded, and raise their prices.The ingredients are unbelievably fresh, and they make an effort to make sure you are eating the best available, and much of the menu is made from scratch on site.  This should be expected at a fine dining restaurant, but celebrated at your local Falafel stand.  There is no playing around with the menu, just order a falafel in pita, and add houmous and feta for 40p/50p respectively.  Simple ingredients done right.

-WAVV2RsVJKat3Iz3GMM_Q.text: Having heard very good things about this place from a colleague, I cast aside desire for lumps of lightly burnt animal on a stick and ventured inside.  The falafel and houmous here are so good that I decided to become a vegetarian.   Having made a success of herbivorism until right up to the evening meal I decided to take it no further.  However, now I've tried it I shall add it to my regular lunch circuit.It gets very busy here at lunch so give yourself a little more time for your take-away.

bZQGoADvOpT0fOy5LM5boA.text: Very impressed with the service here! Friendly, chatty staff and free falafels to try while I make my order. The pitta I got was seriously filling and very tasty with a choice of sauces and add-ons. They'd run out of guac by the time I got there, so I'll deffo have to go back and try it out. My only small gripe was that I couldn't sit and linger over my food as I found it a bit chilly. Then again I'm almost always cold ;)

IqZK1N5ffKTvmEZdhGLh7w.text: On a business trip to London and looking for a quick vegan dinner to take back to the hotel.  I got the falafel container with aubergine.  It was so good!!  Tahini sauce was amazing and like others have said, some of the best falafel I've had.  Crispy outside and soft inside. Not dry at all.  All of the salad toppings were delish.  The young woman who worked there couldn't have been nicer.  Highly recommend.

ZDviObv3vJcMGBKWxdK9zA.text: I am honestly OBSESSED with this place. It's one of those places that you find yourself craving after your 1st...2nd..3rd..19th.. visit. The best falafel I've had in London - by far! (and I've had a lot of falafel)I always recommend Pilpel to anyone who's looking to grab a delicious, inexpensive bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom

D-lW6UN7EwrpoORQC8st9w.text: My husband had the pita with guacamole and I had the container with aubergine both were amazing! Possibly the best falafels we have ever had. We will definitely be back.

69f2jtkDdUsJaC8TIduWMA.text: Yum! Delicious. Affordable. Easy.  I had the plate with everything. Plus aubergine.  For this price you can't beat it.

Rkpr7a9-0AqP87WIu9arJQ.text: This place is fantastic! I ordered the simple £4.80 falafel, salad and houmous pitta (wholemeal/brown option), and it was delicious!!! I thankfully didn't have to queue or wait long to order as I went in at around 8:45pm.It was very filling and so tasty, and the man who served me was lovely and friendly too!Really really recommend this place, for well-priced deliciousness!

cBD0ewGZI6I-M4zIry21Xg.text: Very fast and efficient even during the lunch rush. You get a lot of good quality food for the price. Everything here was well done with good combinations of flavors. I just didn't think it was that standout in terms of falafel, there are much better even in London. I expected something life altering :)

3iPdFeUmT-s9AcjeYEM8JA.text: I changed my definition of falafel after eating here. They really care about what they sell to their customers, and it shows. Their falafels are the best: crispy on the outside, freshly made and hot, and soft on the inside. The bread they put the falafels in are equally good: soft, fluffy and hold their against all the salads, tahini, and hummus they are stuffed with.The best part is that the service is lovely. While you wait in the line, they hand out free falafels and make sure they get your order quick. Brilliant place.

photos.caption: Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom

JIzmZkk8fM0M-ixrvIZXbQ.text: I always used to say that I didn't like falafel until I was offered a taster as I walked past Pilpel. Absolute game changer!The falafel itself was suprisingly tasty and not greasy at all considering that it is fried. There are pretty much 2 main options for how you can have it. Either in a pitta (white or brown) or in a container (with or without pitta). I find that the container is slightly too much and much prefer the pitta as it's easier to get the flavour of everything together.This is where it really comes into it's own. Houmous comes as standard along with tahini and chilli sauce if that's what floats your boat. I tend to lay off the tahini as I think both sauces tend to soak into the bread making it slightly messy. If I wasn't usually eating in work this wouldn't be a problem at all! You can then follow this up with a selection of fresh salad items adding different textures and enhancing the flavour.There's a number of other options that you can pay a little extra to get such as guacamole, sun dried tomatoes and aubergine although in my opinion they aren't really worth the additional cost. Prices are really good, especially for the area with the pitta coming in at £4.80 and the container only £1 more. If you haven't tried Pilpel yet you need to get yourself along and you won't be sorry. In fact you might even see me there!

OsrDhXs_XJgebEfRjvsZYw.text: The McDonald's of falafel, cheap but utterly mediocre. The falafel is decent, worthy of around three or four stars on its own, but unfortunately everything else fails to hit the same level. The pitas served are poor, lacking in fluffiness and various flavors, leaving you with bland, overly chewy dough that takes away from the goodness inside. The other toppings as well lacked the taste of freshness and seemed like left-overs from school canteen salads. And don't get me started on the hummus and the chili and tahini sauces... I reckon that if one had those blind-tasted by random people, none would guess correctly what they just had. They were so bland and flat I completely forgot they even spread them inside. In my opinion, Pilpel just cannot compare against good, authentic falafel stalls. The lone highlights are the rightly cheap price, the well-cooked falafel and the perception of eating healthily when all you're tasting is uncooked frozen salad.

x_GRRGWycA6SBr5Z_IIyEg.text: Best falafel I've ever had, ever..... Whole wheat pita with everything and a splash of chili sauce. Friendly staff and healthy options, what more do you need? Oh ya, a deep fried falafel.... donesky!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Pilpel - London, United Kingdom

URvpQZJwNRp-IVlP0N-3KQ.text: Pilpel is totally gorgeous fresh falafel unlike any you've had before. A rich green soft interior and a crunchy hard seed studded exterior - they pack four or five into your order with a huge range of salad.  Their pickles are especially delish and you can do white or brown pitta or salad with pitta on the side. Huge, filling, well priced. They often give you a taster while you wait. My friend even had Keira Knightley apologise to him over a falafel here.

jO3_itXqBrDcRIXN_9qsEg.text: I'm a new transplant from the States and recently returned from a trip to Jordan. After that trip, I swore I couldn't eat falafel and hoummus outside the Middle East. I'm here to say that Pilpel has convinced me that I was mistaken. The quality of the ingredients is high and the falafels are legitimate. I ordered a standard falafel with all of the salads and extra hot sauce. The pita was as big as my face, and I yet I probably finished it in less than five minutes. Well worth the 5 quid and before I left, I thanked the staff for such a delicious meal. Then, the staff did something which I did not expect. In return for my praise, the owner gave me 5-6 falafels and tahini for free! I am immensely grateful for their kindness and will happily go back to Pilpel (next time, with company).

QfHwErG2pe2s1rAEh8-P_g.text: I visited Pilpel with my friend who is vegan on a Sunday before a bank holiday Monday. The market (just a few yards away) was really busy with many delicious food stalls which explains why we were the only people in this, usually busy, falafel house. Relieved that we had luckily avoided the usual queues, we chose our falafels in pita and sat down. I enjoyed it, my friend enjoyed it even more as she finished every crumb and ordered another! Service was mediocre and they didn't have a loo. I would go back but I don't have the burning desire. On the other hand, my friend declared that she could eat there everyday.

cLbjEugrcqPsJDZHRNXqEg.text: Great tasting - the falafel is beautifully crisp and packed full of flavour, the tahini sauce is incredible as is the chilli. The salad is very fresh and the variety is wonderful, it includes things like chopped herbs, chickpeas, homous, as well as the usual. I have this at least twice a week and never bore of the flavour. Great value - at only £5.45 this is a steal as it's so packed full of flavour and very filling. You can add additional items for just 80p. I would highly recommend getting the aubergine. Very healthy - okay, so the falafel is fried, but a falafel in itself is pretty healthy anyway and the rest of the days packs in good progress towards that 5 a day.Please go here, it's awesome.

Ib8kO7H8spRuh0G0Kyt_mA.text: The queues at this place tell you the whole story.  I'm almost certain that the cafe that was nextdoor a couple of years ago had to close because it was being obscured by the hordes queueing for their daily Pilpel fix.The queue moves quickly; they have their production-line down to a tee, and they quite often bring everyone a hot, fresh falafel while they are waiting.  The staff are all crazily hard-working and friendly.  I'd say the "vibe" was positive, contrary to what other reviews have said.The food is as always good.  The falafel is fantastic and the salad it comes with also great, if you go for all the sauces, at least.  The extras are worth adding once in a while, for example boiled egg or feta.They have another outlet in Spitalfields market now, you don't get the same friendly buzz from the staff there but you may get your food more quickly.

PdmubsSCTsMj029MRmMKGg.text: They only serve one thing so it would be awful if they did not know how to make a decent falafel ... Luckily they do.   The choice is really in a pitta with the salad in or in a box with salad and the pitta on the side. You can egg, feta or aubergine There is always a queue at lunchtime, as with most places in the area.

vAO0TKoYwTaSvSzWVMzIrg.text: Pilpel is falafel heaven. Great value for money. Very nice service, kind staff & clean place in a lovely location. I have had many falafels, but this one takes the cake. One bite and I knew that the reviews weren't over rated. Do have the pita wrap if you can handle eating slightly messy stuff by hand. Else go for the falafel bowl. Either ways you are in for a treat. Hail the good ol man who started it. Much love.

-qw1YtQfL_6qtrMA06JELQ.text: What can I say: I simply love Pilpel! I'm actually a super-regular at their other location by St. Paul's, but the other day I was near Liverpool Street and so I decided to try out the mother ship. (This was actually the original store.)I mean, there's not much that I can add to the other reviews, other than that their concept f.... works! Here's what you should do, when you come here:1) Decide if you're super-hungry (2a) or just hungry (2b). (Don't come here if you're just peckish)2a) Right, you're super-hungry. In that case I suggest you go for the falafel salad in a box. For extra protein and deliciousness, I'd add an egg for an extra 60p. (And if you really want to go crazy, add that dollop of tasty guacamole as well!)2b) You're hungry? Go for the classic falafel sandwich in pita bread - make sure to get the wholemeal pita, as your health will thank you for it! (You can certainly also add all the extras as described above, but let me tell you that eating this will be a messy undertaking!)Now, last but not least, please make sure that especially if you're going for option 2b, you take plenty of napkins with you - as you will need them!

0b3k1DzMIwUIrdSfM8lf9A.text: Tried for the first time today and in complete awe with this tiny wonder and their service. I told them to guide me as I was confused what to order. They guided me well and I had pita bread with lots of salads and falafel... Yummy!!! I soon recommended it to my colleagues who did know about it. One can have a nice wholesome lunch when you don't want to have meat or chicken stuffs.

LJBgyeGTiRRAMdJHytacxg.text: This isn't the best falafel ever. I wish I could take those who have said so round the corner to the pop-up 'Falafel House' and get them to reconsider.However, the portions are generous and the combinations are well thought-out. A little dry in my opinion but all the ingredients are fresh and service is a real delight.Not sure I would choose this place if I was hankering for a falafel if I'm honest, but nice ideas.
